author: ralexstokes
content: <@!703050754717515826> can you just try `curl -v https://goerli.prylabs.net/`?

author: ralexstokes
content: as a sanity check to make sure you can connect from that host?

author: ralexstokes
content: you should get an empty http 200 back

author: 0x0078e
content:
I'm embarrassed:  you may have hit it straight up:       
$: curl -v https://goerli.prylabs.net/
* Could not resolve host: goerli.prylabs.net
* Closing connection 0
curl: (6) Could not resolve host: goerli.prylabs.net

author: donschoe
content:
```
You are about to submit 64 transactions of 32.000000000 Eth. This is irreversible, please make sure you understand the consequences. Are you sure you want to continue? [y/n]^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^M^C
```

Pressing `[ENTER]` sends `^M` instead of return

author: donschoe
content: I mean `^M` is the carriage return, but why does Teku not accept it as one?

author: donschoe
content: `Are you sure you want to continue? [y/n]yes^My^Myyy^M^M^M^C`

author: donschoe
content: Nevemind, that was an issue with `zsh`

author: terence0083
content: I'm back. Looking at this now. One thing that's on top of my mind, is we haven't updated proposer's eth1 voting scheme since v0.9.0 of the spec. Not sure if this issue could be attributed due to difference in terms of how proposer votes for eth1 data

author: nishant0
content: I dont think so

author: nishant0
content: that block hash doesn't exist at all

author: nishant0
content: even if our proposer voting scheme is slightly different, we should not be voting for a non-existent block

author: terence0083
content: Right. It does sound like what Preston has described. Our proposer votes for a random block if it's not correctly conencted with eth1

author: prestonvanloon
content: it's probably bad eth1 info from the eth1 node

author: prestonvanloon
content: we'll turn down our public eth1 endpoint for the official MC net

author: prestonvanloon
content: this isn't cache related

author: prestonvanloon
content: actually yeah it could be cache related

author: prestonvanloon
content: https://github.com/prysmaticlabs/prysm/blob/cb045dd0e360192fb9e46314b3954f3bf58f4871/beacon-chain/powchain/block_reader.go#L101

author: djrtwo
content: the weird part is the correctness of the other two fields

author: prestonvanloon
content: ok so i think Prysm has a bug where it is eagerly caching all of these eth1 blocks. When it saw this block, it immediately cached it in memory. There could he been a reorg of distance 1 and the cache might not have been updated. This cache needs to be reworked or disable for mainnet

author: djrtwo
content: ahhh

author: djrtwo
content: that's interesting

author: prestonvanloon
content: that is my immediate thinking anyway, i don't have supporting evidence yet

author: nishant0
content: if this is correct, a restart will fix this

author: nishant0
content: so that would unblock us for now to include new deposits

author: prestonvanloon
content: yep or waiting 1024 slots will fix it

author: prestonvanloon
content: whenever the round changes

author: djrtwo
content: solid theory nonetheless and something to investigate regardless

author: djrtwo
content: breaking for some dinner. have a nice weekend everyone!

author: prestonvanloon
content: yes, as Terence said, we haven't looked at this routine seriously since 0.9 or even earlier
